body.p: This is an unusual example - it is not surprising that East/West can make seven tricks in spades, but it is surprising that South can make .

The void in spades means the defense cannot take its six tricks. South starts with seven tricks plus an easy trick to set up in diamonds. A heart lead gives up a ninth trick. If West leads a club, South wins in hand, and immediately leads a diamond. If West flies the ace, declarer wins the continuation, cashes the diamond king and clubs, leading to this position:
West was forced to pitch a diamond to protect the heart suit. Now declarer exits a diamond, and West gets three tricks in the suit, but then must concede the last two heart tricks.
If West had ducked the diamond lead, a substantially similar position results, only with one more diamond in North, South, and West.
Of course, if East is declarer in 4S, he has an easy -500, with seven top tricks.
